newsitem.title: UK: Arabian sugar refineries to cut IOR demand - ISO.
newsitem.headline: Arabian sugar refineries to cut IOR demand - ISO.

text.p: The advent of new sugar refineries in the Middle East Gulf could cause white sugar purchases by Indian Ocean Rim (IOR) nations to decrease by 30 percent, the International Sugar Organization (ISO) said on Tuesday.

"The existing structure of white/raw sugar imports of the IOR will suffer major changes in the near future as the (Middle East) Gulf countries have started developing sizeable refining capacities," the ISO said in a report released at the start of its two-day seminar on the IOR region in London.

It said the Al Khaleej refinery in Dubai was already in operation, with an annual designed tolling capacity of 700,000 tonnes, and Saudi Arabia's refinery at Jeddah planned to produce 50,000 tonnes of white sugar from early 1997.
In addition, plans to establish a refinery in Oman had recently been expanded with a forecast annual capacity possibly doubled to 360,000 tonnes, the ISO said.

"Thus, the replacement of more than 1.5 million tonnes of white sugar by raw sugar can be anticipated and the shift in import demand may result in a 30-percent decrease of white sugar buyings," the ISO report said.
"Consequently, with all refineries working to full capacity, raw sugar imports for the IOR would increase 75 percent above the 1995 level," it added.
IOR countries numbered 18 in Asia and 15 in Africa and Australia, the ISO said.
The region's sugar imports were highly dependent on developments in India and were generally dominated by white sugar.
With 4.8 million tonnes, IOR importers purchased nearly 30 percent of the world total for gross white sugar imports in 1995, the report said.
